member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler
member.summary:
Default WinStore component that handles the authorization errors returned by the requests to the ArcGIS resources. This implementation is based on the .
Optionally, depending on the value, the credentials are cached in the in a secure manner. The roams credentials to other Windows8 systems, so they can be retrieved on all PCs and tablets.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.IChallengeHandler
member.summary: ChallengeHandler interface for handling the authorization errors returned by the requests to the ArcGIS resources.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.IChallengeHandler.CreateCredentialAsync(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.CredentialRequestInfo)
member.summary: Create the credential allowing to access to the specified ArcGIS resource. Most generally the application challenges the user in order to get the credential but the credential may also be generated programmatically.
member.param: Information about the ArcGIS resource that needs a credential for getting access to.
member.returns: a Task object with upon successful completion. Otherwise, the Task.Exception is set.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler.ClearCredentialsCache
member.summary: Clears all ArcGISRuntime credentials from the Credential Locker.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler.RetrieveAllSavedCredentials
member.summary: Retrieves all ArcGISRuntime credentials stored in the Credential Locker.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler.CreateCredentialAsync(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.CredentialRequestInfo)
member.summary: Challenge for getting the credential allowing to access to the specified ArcGIS resource.
member.param: Information about the ArcGIS resource that needs a credential for getting access to.
member.returns: a Task object with upon successful completion. Otherwise, the Task.Exception is set.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler.AllowSaveCredentials
member.summary:
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the credentials can be saved in the credential locker.
The first time AllowSaveCredentials is set to true, the cached credentials are added to the IdentityManager

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Security.DefaultChallengeHandler.CredentialSaveOption
member.summary: Gets or sets the option that specifies the initial state of the dialog's Save Credential check box. The default value is clear (unchecked).

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.ArcGISServices.ImageFormat.JPGPNG
member.summary: JPG | PNG. Supported in Image Service only.
member.remarks: Note that support for the jpgpng format was added at 10.0 This format returns a JPG if there are no transparent pixels in the requested extent, otherwise it returns a PNG.

member.summary: PNG. Supported in Map Service only.

member.summary: JPEG. Supported in both Image Service and Map Service.

member.summary: PNG32. Supported in Image Service and Map Service.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.Editor
member.summary: Editor used for performing edits on a map.

remarks.para: An editor can only be associated with one map instance.

example.para: Demonstrates sketching various geometric shapes on the map via the Editor.RequestShapeAsync method. The sketches are then added as Graphics in a GraphicsLayer and drawn on the map.

img.alt: Example of sketching multiple shape types with the Editor.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.Editor.DeleteVertex
member.summary: Method invoked to remove vertex from a multipart geometry or Use the CommandParameter to specify the coordinate index of vertex to be removed. Otherwise, select vertex by PointerPress or MouseDown to enable delete on selected vertex. Note also that in order to remove vertex, the multipart geometry must contain its minimum number of vertices required to make it a valid geometry. For example, Polyline must at least have 2 vertices and Polygon must at least have 3 vertices.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView
member.summary: MapView Control.

remarks.para: The MapView is a container that holds a Map. A Map holds a collection of layers. Layers are visual representations of geographic information and come in many forms. The types of layers that are displayed in a MapView are two dimensional in nature; meaning they are displayed in X/Y (a.k.a. Latitude/Longitude) coordinate space.
There is only one Map per MapView and it is set by the MapView.Map Property. Multiple Map objects can be created and swapped out dynamically as the application is running in the MapView.

img.alt: Demonstrates knowing when layers have loaded successfully in the MapView.

member.param: A list of Layers, all of which are currently in the Map.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.ViewBase.SetView(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.Viewpoint)
member.summary: Sets the view of the map from the given Viewpoint.

remarks.para: A Viewpoint object is a helper object that is used to specify either (1) the center of the map typically at a specified scale or (2) the extent of map using a bounding box of an Envelope. If it is desired to set the initial extent of a map via XAML, the only way this can be accomplished is via a Viewpoint object or one of its inherited children: ViewpointCenter or ViewpointExtent. Defining a ViewPoint or one of its inherited children can be done via a constructor and/or setting some of the many Properties that are available.
An in-depth discussion on the various options for changing the viewable extent of layers in the map can be found in the Fundamentals document: Setting Extents.

example.para: Demonstrates using the various MapView.SetView Methods to adjust the extent of the map.

img.alt: Changing the extent of the map via the SetView Method.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.ViewBase.Overlays
member.summary: Gets the XAML elements that can be used to overlay on the map, and placed using the MapOverlayAnchor attached property.

remarks.para: The term 'overlay' in the ArcGIS Runtime .NET SDK may be new to some developers. In other Esri SDK's the concept of an overlay is often termed a 'MapTip'. A MapTip is a user-assistance component that displays an on-screen description of a map feature when the mouse is paused over or a users taps on a feature.

In order to maintain good performance in your application it is recommended to not place too many or overly complex UIElement objects within the UIElementCollection. These graphical UIElement objects are drawn via software rendering of the Operating System and performance can vary across devices. Keeping UIElements to a minimum, say under 20, should not impact the performance of your application when setting the MapView.Overlays Property.

example.para: Demonstrates displaying a UIElement on top of the MapView using the MapView.Overlays Property. This is useful for performing MapTip functionality.

img.alt: Performing a MapTip display of the city name in a FeatureLayer via the MapView.Overlays Property.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.SetView(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Navigates to the bounding geometry.
member.param: Geometry to fit the view to.

remarks.para: If the boundingGeometry parameter is a point or a geometry with an zero-extent, a pan will be performed, else a zoom.
An in-depth discussion on the various options for changing the viewable extent of layers in the map can be found in the Fundamentals document: Setting Extents.

example.para: Demonstrates using the various MapView.SetView Methods to adjust the extent of the map.

img.alt: Changing the extent of the map via the SetView Method.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.SetView(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MapPoint)
member.summary: Centers the view on the provided point.
member.param: Point to center the view on.

remarks.para: The scale of the map is not change. The map merely shifts to the center of the new point at the current scale.
An in-depth discussion on the various options for changing the viewable extent of layers in the map can be found in the Fundamentals document: Setting Extents.

example.para: Demonstrates using the various MapView.SetView Methods to adjust the extent of the map.

img.alt: Changing the extent of the map via the SetView Method.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.SetView(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MapPoint,System.Double)
member.summary: Centers the view on the provided point at the specified scale.
member.param: Point to center the view on.
Map scale to fit the view to.

remarks.para: Scale means the ratio or relationship between a distance or area on a map and the corresponding distance or area on the ground, commonly expressed as a fraction or ratio. A map scale of 1/100,000 or 1:100,000 means that one unit of measure on the map equals 100,000 of the same unit on the earth.
An in-depth discussion on the various options for changing the viewable extent of layers in the map can be found in the Fundamentals document: Setting Extents.

example.para: Demonstrates using the various MapView.SetView Methods to adjust the extent of the map.

img.alt: Changing the extent of the map via the SetView Method.

member.param: Zoom factor greater than zero. Less than one zooms out, greater than one zooms in.
member.returns: True if the zoom animation completed, false if it was interrupted by another view navigation.

member.name: E:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.ExtentChanged
member.summary: Occurs when map extent changed.

example.para: Shows how to set the initial extent of the map (Map.InitialViewpoint) in code.

img.alt: Code example using the Map.ExtentChanged Event.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.Map
member.summary: The current Map content displayed in the MapView

remarks.para: The MapView is a container that holds a Map. A Map holds a collection of layers. Layers are visual representations of geographic information and come in many forms. The types of layers that are displayed in a MapView are two dimensional in nature; meaning they are displayed in X/Y (a.k.a. Latitude/Longitude) coordinate space.
There is only one Map per MapView and it is set by the MapView.Map Property. Multiple Map objects can be created and swapped out dynamically as the application is running in the MapView.

To set the SpatialReference of the MapView, a Map must be added to the MapView.Map Property and either: (1) the Map.InitialViewpoint must be set (including the Envelope's Extent and SpatialReference) or (2) at least one layer (which has SpatialReference information) must be added to the Map's LayerCollection (typically via the Map.Layers.Add() Method).

example.para: Demonstrates switching out different Map objects (with different layers) for the MapView.Map Property.

img.alt: Code example using the MapView.Map Property to swap out multiple Map objects..

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.SpatialReference
member.summary: Gets the spatial reference of the map.

remarks.para: This Property only obtains the SpatialReference. To set the SpatialReference of the MapView, a Map must be added to the MapView.Map Property and either: (1) the Map.InitialViewpoint must be set (including the Envelope's Extent and SpatialReference) or (2) at least one layer (which has SpatialReference information) must be added to the Map's LayerCollection (typically via the Map.Layers.Add() Method).

example.para: Demonstrates resetting the MapView.SpatialReference by setting it to a new Map.

img.alt: Changing the MapView.SpatialReference.

member.remarks: Returns if the map isn't in a ready-state.

member.summary: Gets the current size of each device independent pixel in map units.
member.remarks: Returns if the map isn't in a ready-state.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.MaximumExtent
member.summary: Gets or sets the extent the map should be retained to.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.MaxScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum scale for which this map can be zoomed in to. A smaller number allows the map to zoom further in.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the map unbounded by any scale.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView.MinScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum scale for which this map can be zoomed out to. A large number allows the map to zoom further out.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the map unbounded by any scale.

member.remarks: Note that not all spatial references supports this mode, and setting it to true in those cases, this property will have no effect.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Data.FeatureSet
member.summary: Instances of this class represent a feature set. A feature set is simply a collection of features. Each feature is represented as a Graphic object. They may contain geometry, attributes, and symbology. If the features contain only attributes but no geometry, the feature set can be considered a simple table where each feature is a row object.
member.remarks: A feature set can be the result of a task or used as an input to a task. Tasks that return a feature set include and . In addition, Geoprocessor may require a feature set as input.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Data.ShapefileTable
member.summary: Represents a Shapefile table

remarks.para: The minimum required files needed to open a shapefile is the main ".shp" file (specified in , the ".dbf" file and the ".shx" files.
Shapefiles do not support editing, and calls to add/update/delete operations will throw a . When performing edits on tables, check the property, which will return false for this table type.

It is recommended to always set the SpatialReference for the Map when using a FeatureLayer based on a local disk based FeatureTable such as a . The reason is that the visual elements of the FeatureLayer may not display if the Shapefile is not based on the SpatialReference WKID of 3787 (aka. Web Mercator). By specifying the Map's SpatialReference to be exactly the same at the ShapefileTable, you will be assured that it displays visually in the Map.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ConvertCoordinate
member.summary: Provides methods for converting from MapPoint geometries to coordinate notation strings and methods for converting from coordinate notations to MapPoint geometries.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ConvertCoordinate.FromMgrs(System.String,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.SpatialReference,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MgrsConversionMode)
member.summary: Converts a coordinate notation string in the Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) format to a MapPoint geometry with the specified spatial reference.
member.param: A representing the coordinate notation to be converted.
A representing the geographic or projected coordinate system of the returned MapPoint.
A value determining the spheroid used in the conversion and the zone in which the 180 longitude falls.
member.returns: A MapPoint representing the location defined by the coordinates. Note that the location defined by an MGRS coordinate string is an area, not a specific point; however, the returned MapPoint represents the lower left corner of the area that the MGRS string represents.

remarks.para: The Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) is a grid-based system used to represent locations on the universal transverse Mercator (UTM) and universal polar stereographic (UPS) grid systems, expressed as an alphanumeric string. An MGRS coordinate defines an area on the Earth's surface as opposed to a specific point. A fully qualified MGRS string is 15 characters long and consists of the following three components: grid zone designation, 100,000-meter square identifier, and easting/northing.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ConvertCoordinate.FromMgrs(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.String},Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.SpatialReference,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MgrsConversionMode)
member.summary: Converts a collection of coordinate notation strings in the Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) format to a collection of MapPoint geometries each with the same specified spatial reference.
member.param: A of representing the coordinate notations to be converted.
A representing the geographic or projected coordinate system of each MapPoint in the returned collection.
A value determining the spheroid used in the conversion and the zone in which the 180 longitude falls.
member.returns: A of representing the locations defined by the input coordinate notations. Note that the location defined by an MGRS coordinate string is an area, not a specific point; however, the returned MapPoint represents the lower left corner of the area that the MGRS string represents.

remarks.para: The Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) is a grid-based system used to represent locations on the universal transverse Mercator (UTM) and universal polar stereographic (UPS) grid systems, expressed as an alphanumeric string. An MGRS coordinate defines an area on the Earth's surface as opposed to a specific point. A fully qualified MGRS string is 15 characters long and consists of the following three components: grid zone designation, 100,000-meter square identifier, and easting/northing.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ConvertCoordinate.ToMgrs(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MapPoint,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MgrsConversionMode,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a MapPoint geometry to a coordinate notation string in the Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) format. The MapPoint must have a valid SpatialReference.
member.param: A representing the location to be converted. Note that the location defined by an MGRS coordinate string is an area, not a specific point.
A value determining the spheroid used in the conversion and the zone in which the 180 longitude falls.
A greater than or equal to 1 and typically less than or equal to 5 indicating the required precision of returned MGRS coordinate string.
if the MGRS coordinate should be rounded to produce a lower precision coordinate notation; otherwise to truncate the coordinate notation.
if spaces should be added to the returned MGRS coordinate notation; otherwise .
member.returns: A in the requested coordinate notation format representing the location defined by the MapPoint.
member.exception: The numerOfDigits parameter must be greater than or equal to 1.

remarks.para: The Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) is a grid-based system used to represent locations on the universal transverse Mercator (UTM) and universal polar stereographic (UPS) grid systems, expressed as an alphanumeric string. An MGRS coordinate defines an area on the Earth's surface as opposed to a specific point. A fully qualified MGRS string is 15 characters long and consists of the following three components: grid zone designation, 100,000-meter square identifier, and easting/northing.

The number of digits refers to the digits in each part of the numerical grid reference and must be greater than or equal to 1 and typically less than or equal to 5 , indicating the precision as follows:
1 digit represents 10,000m precision e.g. 18SUU80
2 digits represents 1,000m precision e.g. 18SUU8401
3 digits represents 100m precision e.g. 18SUU836014
4 digits represents 10m precision e.g. 18SUU83630143
5 digits represents 1m precision e.g. 18SUU8362601432

When changing precision levels, it is important to truncate rather than round the easting and northing values to ensure the more precise polygon will remain within the boundaries of the less precise polygon.

remarks.para: The Military Grid Reference System (MGRS) is a grid-based system used to represent locations on the universal transverse Mercator (UTM) and universal polar stereographic (UPS) grid systems, expressed as an alphanumeric string. An MGRS coordinate defines an area on the Earth's surface as opposed to a specific point. A fully qualified MGRS string is 15 characters long and consists of the following three components: grid zone designation, 100,000-meter square identifier, and easting/northing.

The number of digits refers to the digits in each part of the numerical grid reference and must be a value greater than or equal to 1 and typically less than or equal to 5, indicating the precision as follows:
1 digit represents 10,000m precision e.g. 18SUU80
2 digits represents 1,000m precision e.g. 18SUU8401
3 digits represents 100m precision e.g. 18SUU836014
4 digits represents 10m precision e.g. 18SUU83630143
5 digits represents 1m precision e.g. 18SUU8362601432

When changing precision levels, it is important to truncate rather than round the easting and northing values to ensure the more precise polygon will remain within the boundaries of the less precise polygon.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ConvertCoordinate.ToGeoref(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.MapPoint,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Converts a MapPoint geometry to a coordinate notation string in the World Geographic Reference system (GEOREF) format.
member.param: A representing the location to be converted.

A indicating the precision of each half of the numeric portion of the returned coordinate. Must not be 0. A value of 1 or 2 will return a coordinate to 1 minute precision (e.g. MKPG1214). A value of 3 represents 0.1 minutes (e.g. MKPG120140). A value of 4 represents 0.01 minutes (e.g. MKPG12001400).
if the GEOREF coordinate should be rounded to produce a lower precision coordinate notation; otherwise to truncate the coordinate notation.
member.returns: A in the requested coordinate notation format representing the location defined by the MapPoint.

remarks.para:
The GEOREF coordinate MKPG1214 comprises:
The 15 degree quadrangle e.g. MK
The 1 degree quadrangle e.g. PG
The 1 minute longitude latitude e.g. 1214.
Each additional pair of digits represents a tenfold increase in the precision e.g. 6 digits = 0.01 minutes, 8 digits = 0.01 minutes.

member.exception: The numerOfDigits parameter must be greater than or equal to 1.

member.summary: Axis Aligned envelope

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry
member.summary: Abstract Geometry class provides a base class for objects that define geometric shapes. Geometry objects can be used as geometry definitions for rendering data.

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry.m_canBeAssignedToGraphic
member.summary:
Flag indicating if it is safe to set the m_coreGeometry on a Graphic. "Safe" means that we can be sure that this CoreGeometry hasn't been assigned to a Graphic.
If the Geometry's CoreGeometry was created by managed code, we know it's not assigned to a Graphic, so the flag is set.
Any Geometry objects that were created with a constructor that takes an ICoreGeometry have the flag set to false, because we don't know where it came from. It might be set on a Graphic.
This flag is set to false when Geometries are cloned, on both the clone and the "original", because after this has happened, there's no single place where we can keep track of whether the Geometry has been assigned to a graphic.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions
member.summary: Enumeration that defines how an extend operation can be performed

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.Default
member.summary: By default, extension considers both ends of paths. The old ends remain and new points are added at the extended ends. The new points have attributes that are extrapolated from adjacent existing segments.

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.RelocateEnds
member.summary: If an extension is performed at an end, relocate the end point to the new position instead of leaving the old point and adding a new point at the new position.

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.KeepEndAttributes
member.summary: If an extension is performed at an end, do not extrapolate the end-segment's attributes for the new point. Instead, make its attributes the same as the current end. Incompatible with .

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.NoEndAttributes
member.summary: If an extension is performed at an end, do not extrapolate the end-segment's attributes for the new point. Instead, make its attributes be empty. Incompatible with .

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.NoExtendAtFrom
member.summary: Do not extend the 'from' end of any path.

member.name: F:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions.NoExtendAtTo
member.summary: Do not extend the 'to' end of any path.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Cut(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Polyline)
member.summary: Performs a cut operation on a geometry with a .
member.param: The geometry to be cut by the given polyline.
The polyline used to cut the geometry in half.
member.returns: A collection of geometries describing the cut, fit first is to the left and second to the right. See remarks for more details.
member.remarks: For Polylines, all left cuts will be grouped together in the first Geometry, right cuts and coincident cuts are grouped in the second Geometry, and each undefined cut, along with any uncut parts, are output as separate Polylines. For Polygons, all left cuts are grouped in the first Polygon, all right cuts are in the second Polygon, and each undefined cut, along with any left-over parts after cutting, are output as a separate Polygon. If there were no cuts then there will be no returned geometries.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Simplify(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Simplifies the given geometry to make it topologically consistent according to their geometry type. For instance, it rectifies polygons that may be self-intersecting, or contain incorrect ring orientations.
member.returns: The simplified geometry.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Area(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Gets the simple area for the Geometry passed in. This is a planar measurement using 2D Cartesian mathematics to compute the area.
member.param: The geometry to calculate the area for.
member.returns: The computed area in the same units as the geometry's spatial reference unit.
member.para: The geometry must be topologically correct to get its accurate area. Geometries returned by ArcGIS Server services are always correct. If you construct geometries programmatically or using the sketch layer, or if you modify geometries returned by ArcGIS Server, you should simplify them using .

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.GeodesicArea(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeodeticCurveType)
member.summary: Gets the geodesic area of a polygon.
member.param: The geometry to calculate the geodesic area for.
The type of curve to calculate.
member.returns: The calculated geodesic area in square meters.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Length(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Gets the length for a specified Geometry. This is a planar measurement using 2D Cartesian mathematics to compute the length.
member.param: The geometry to calculate the area for.
member.returns: The calculated length in the same units as the geometry's spatial reference unit.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.GeodesicLength(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeodeticCurveType)
member.summary: Gets the geodesic length for the Geometry passed in. Geodesic length is calculated using only the vertices of the polygon and define the lines between the points as geodesic segments independent of the actual shape of the polygon. A geodesic segment is the shortest path between two points on an ellipsoid. Thus, if you have a line that spans the width of the world, with only two vertices, each on the edges of the map, the geodesic length would be zero (shortest distance between the two vertices).
member.param: The geometry to calculate the geodesic length for.
The type of curve to calculate.
member.returns: The calculated geodesic length in meters.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Buffer(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a buffer polygon at the specified distance around the given geometry.
member.param: The distance in the unit of the geometry's spatial reference for which to buffer the geometry.
member.returns: The polygon that represents the buffered area.

example.para: Demonstrates using the powerful GeometryEngine local process to generate graphic buffer polygons based upon a user specified radius and mouse-clicks/taps on the map.

img.alt: Creates buffer polygons based upon user mouse-clicks/taps on the map.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Buffer(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry},System.Double)
member.summary: Creates buffers at the specified distance around the given geometries. Will union the results of all buffers.
member.param: The distance in the unit of the geometry's spatial reference for which to buffer the geometries.
member.returns: The polygon that represents the buffered area.

example.para: Demonstrates using the powerful GeometryEngine local process to generate a single graphic buffer (unioned) based upon multiple points provided by user interaction with the map.

img.alt: Creating a single unioned buffer from multiple points provided by interaction with the map.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Densify(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,System.Double)
member.summary: Densifies the specified geometry.
member.param: The maximum segment length allowed. Must be a positive value. Curves are densified to straight segments using the maxSegmentLength. Curves are split into shorter subcurves such that the length of subcurves is shorter than maxSegmentLength. After that the curves are replaced with straight segments.
member.returns: Returns the densified geometry. (It does nothing to geometries with dimension less than 1, but simply passes them along).

member.summary: Densifies the specified geometries.
member.param: The maximum segment length allowed. Must be a positive value. Curves are densified to straight segments using the maxSegmentLength. Curves are split into shorter subcurves such that the length of subcurves is shorter than maxSegmentLength. After that the curves are replaced with straight segments.
member.returns: Returns the densified geometries. (It does nothing to geometries with dimension less than 1, but simply passes them along).

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Offset(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,System.Double,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.OffsetType,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns offset version of the input geometry. The offset operation creates a geometry that is a constant distance from an input polyline or polygon. It is similar to buffering, but produces a one sided result. If offset distance > 0, then the offset geometry is constructed to the right of the oriented input geometry, otherwise it is constructed to the left. For a simple polygon, the orientation of outer rings is clockwise and for inner rings it is counter clockwise. So the "right side" of a simple polygon is always its inside. The bevelRatio is multiplied by the offset distance and the result determines how far a mitered offset intersection can be from the input curve before it is beveled.
member.param: The geometry to calculate offset for. MapPoint and Multipoint are not supported.
The offset distance for the geometry.
The offset type of the offset geometry.
The ratio used to produce a bevel join instead of a miter join (used only when joins is miter)

The maximum distance of the resulting segments compared to the true circular arc (used only when joins is round). If flattenError is 0, tolerance value is used. Also, the algorithm never produces more than around 180 vetices for each round join.
member.returns: Returns the result of the offset operation.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Offset(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry},System.Double,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.OffsetType,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns offset version of the input geometry.The offset operation creates a geometry that is a constant distance from an input polyline or polygon. It is similar to buffering, but produces a one sided result. If offset distance > 0, then the offset geometry is constructed to the right of the oriented input geometry, otherwise it is constructed to the left. For a simple polygon, the orientation of outer rings is clockwise and for inner rings it is counter clockwise. So the "right side" of a simple polygon is always its inside. The bevelRatio is multiplied by the offset distance and the result determines how far a mitered offset intersection can be from the input curve before it is beveled.
member.param: The geometries to calculate offset for. MapPoint and Multipoint are not supported.
The offset distance for the geometry.
The offset type of the offset geometry.
The ratio used to produce a bevel join instead of a miter join (used only when joins is miter)

The maximum distance of the resulting segments compared to the true circular arc (used only when joins is round). If flattenError is 0, tolerance value is used. Also, the algorithm never produces more than around 180 vertices for each round join.
member.returns: Returns the result of the offset operation.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.GeodesicSector(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeodesicSectorParameters)
member.summary: The function returns a piecewise approximation of a geodesic ellipse (or geodesic circle, if SemiAxis1Length = SemiAxis2Length). Constructs a geodesic ellipse centered on the specified point. If this method is used to generate a polygon or a polyline, the result may have more than one path, depending on the size of the sector and its position relative to the horizon of the coordinate system. When the method generates a polyline or a multipoint, the result vertices lie on the boundary of the ellipse. When a polygon is generated, the interior of the polygon is the interior of the sector, however the boundary of the polygon may contain segments from the spatial reference horizon, or from the GCS extent.
member.param: The geodesic sector parameter that describes how to draw the geodesic sector.
member.returns: The geometry that contains sector of the geodesic ellipse.
member.exception: Only Polygon, Polyline and Multipoint are supported for OutputGeometryType

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.GeodesicEllipse(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeodesicEllipseParameters)
member.summary: The function returns a piecewise approximation of a geodesic ellipse (or geodesic circle, if semiAxis1Length = semiAxis2Length). Constructs a geodesic ellipse centered on the specified point.If this method is used to generate a polygon or a polyline, the result may have more than one path, depending on the size of the ellipse and its position relative to the horizon of the coordinate system. When the method generates a polyline or a multipoint, the result vertices lie on the boundary of the ellipse. When a polygon is generated, the interior of the polygon is the interior of the ellipse, however the boundary of the polygon may contain segments from the spatial reference horizon, or from the GCS extent.
member.param: The geodesic ellipse parameter that describes how to create the geodesic ellipse.
member.returns: The geometry that contains the geodesic ellipse.
member.exception: Only Polygon, Polyline and Multipoint are supported for OutputGeometryType
member.remarks: If the smaller axis is zero, the ellipse will degenerate to a line segment, a point, or an empty geometry (depending on the larger axis and output type). Otherwise, if VertextCount < 10, the number of vertices will default to 10.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.ConvexHull(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Returns the convex hull of a geometry
member.returns: A geometry that represents the convex hull

remarks.para: A convex hull is the smallest polygon that encloses a group of objects, such as points. Visually, the boundary of a convex hull polygon is the shape a rubber band would take around a group of objects.

img.alt: Convex hull diagram.

example.para: Demonstrates using the powerful GeometryEngine local process to generate a convex hull graphic polygon based upon user specified mouse-clicks/taps on the map.

img.alt: Showing the generation of a convex hull polygon using multiple points as inputs.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Boundary(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary:
Performs a boundary operation on a single geometry.
For Point - returns an empty point.
For Multipoint - returns an empty point.
For Polyline - returns a multipoint.
For Polygon - returns a polyline that bounds the polygon (adds all rings of the polygon to a polyline).
member.param: The geometry to calculate the boundary for.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Boundary(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry})
member.summary:
Performs a boundary operation on a collection of geometry.
For Point - returns an empty point.
For Multipoint - returns an empty point.
For Polyline - returns a multipoint.
For Polygon - returns a polyline that bounds the polygon (adds all rings of the polygon to a polyline).
member.param: The geometries to calculate the boundaries for.

member.summary: The AutoComplete operation simplifies the process of constructing new polygons that are adjacent to other polygons. It constructs polygons that fill in the gaps between existing polygons and a set of polylines.

member.summary: Reshapes the specified geometry.
member.param: The geometry to be reshaped. This geometry can be either a Polygon or a Polyline.
The polyline used to reshape the geometry.
member.exception: This exception is thrown if MulitPoint, MapPoint or Envelope are passed in the geometry parameter.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.Extend(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Polyline,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Polyline,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.ExtendOptions)
member.summary: Performs the extend operation on a polyline using a polyline as the extender. The output polyline will have the first and last segment of each path extended to the extender if the segments can be interpolated to intersect the extender. In the case that the segments can be extended to multiple segments of the extender, the shortest extension is chosen. Only end points for paths that are not shared by the end points of other paths will be extended. If the polyline cannot be extended by the input extender, then a nullptr will be returned.
member.param: The type of extend operation to perform.
member.exception: Throws InvalidOperationException if both ExtendOptions.NoEndAttributes and ExtendOptions.KeepEndAttributes flags are sent together.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.ShapePreservingLength(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.LinearUnit)
member.summary: Calculates the length of the geometry on the surface of the Earth ellipsoid. This method preserves the shape of the geometry in its coordinate system. This means the true length will be calculated for the geometry you see in the map. Thus, if you have a line that spans the width of the world, with only two vertices, each on edges of the map, the length returned would be comparable to the distance on earth.
member.param: Calculate the length of the geometry.
The unit of measurement that needs to be calculated.
member.returns: Length of the geometry expressed in the unit of measurement provided.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.GeometryEngine.ShapePreservingArea(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.AreaUnit)
member.summary: Calculates the area of the geometry on the surface of the Earth ellipsoid. This method preserves the shape of the geometry in its coordinate system. This means the true area will be calculated for the geometry you see in the map.
member.param: Calculate the area of the geometry.
The unit of measurement that needs to be calculated.
member.returns: Area of the geometry expressed in the unit of measurement provided.

member.returns: Geodesic distance between the two points expressed in the unit of measurement provided.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Polygon
member.summary: A collection of Rings used to represent a Polygon .

remarks.para: A polygon is a closed shape defined by one or more rings. Each ring is a connected sequence of x,y coordinate pairs, where the first and last coordinate pair are the same and all other pairs are unique. If a polygon has more than one ring, the rings may be separate from one another or they may nest inside one another, but they may not overlap. When defining the x,y coordinate pairs in a ring, it is not necessary to specify the first and last coordinate pair to have the same coordinate values. The API automatically closes the ring by connecting a segment between the first and last coordinate pair.

Note: Interior rings to make donut polygons should be counter-clockwise in direction to be topology correct. If there is ever a doubt about the topological correctness of a polygon, call the GeometryEngine.Simplify method to correct any issues. This is especially true if you pass a polygon to ArcGIS Server for a geoprocessing task to avoid any ArcGIS Server errors being thrown.

example.para: Demonstrates creating a simple polygon, donut polygon, and multiple ring polygon via code-behind. An option to view coordinate information for each vertex in the polygons is provided.

img.alt: Example of creating a simple polygon, donut polygon, and multiple ring polygon.

remarks.para: Each spatial reference can be represented by either a well-known ID (wkid), or a well-known text (wkt). Spatial References define the spatial properties of a geometry, for instance the coordinate system it uses. There are 2 broad classes of coordinate systems - Geographic & Projected. A Geographic Coordinate system uses a 3-dimensional spherical surface to define locations on the earth. A Projected Coordinate system on the other hand uses a flat, 2-dimensional surface. More information about spatial references and coordinate systems is available here.
It is very important to associate spatial data, such as geometry objects, with corresponding spatial references.

member.summary: Initializes this instance from whats set in _def, if its invalid an exception is thrown

member.param: If true it will ignore if one sr is null and another is valid

member.summary: Checks incomming SR and compares to an existing SR (typically in a field of a class) and takes on a new SR if the srRef is null If fieldSR is not null (ie SR already established) then the SR's are compared and exception thrown if they don't match

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.SpatialReference.AreEqual(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.SpatialReference,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.SpatialReference,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true of the Spatial references are the same , this includes where older refer to the same underlying spatial reference as a newer id.
member.remarks: Some SpatialReferences can have older referring to the same underlying definition. An example is the Web mercator old id of 102100 and 3857 are both considered to be equal.
member.param: The spatial reference to compare to.
if set to true if one is null and the other is not, the two will be considered the same.
member.returns: true is the two spatial references are the same.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Http.ArcGISHttpClientHandler.DefaultReferer
member.summary: Gets or sets the default referer used by default for all requests going through .

remarks.para: A referer is text in the Http header that is passed between web requests of the client application and web server.

In many scenarios, the referer is used to provide the web server how the incoming web request was initiated. For example a user clicked a particular hyperlink on a web page and the referer gets populated with that hyperlink. The referer is often the URL of the previous web page from which a link was followed. Some companies use referer information to find out user internet browsing patterns for their internet site. Setting referer information in the Http header of a web request is many times required by secured web sites so they can ensure that only approved users are using their resources.

IMPORTANT
Setting a string value for the DefaultReferer Property to the correct referer is necessary in order to gain access to ArcGIS Server web services that require long term tokens for authentication. ArcGIS Online and ArcGIS Portal require long term token for web services that are secured. Depending on the development platform, specifying the correct string for the IdentityManager.TokenGeneration Property can be imperative to accessing secured services by the IdentityManager.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Hydrographic.HydrographicS57Layer
member.summary: A layer that reads S-57 files and displays them following the S-52 specification.

remarks.para: An HydrographicS57Layer is a layer that comprises one or more S-57 files (*.000) conforming to the International Hydrographic Organization (IHO) Transfer Standard for Digital Hydrographic Data, and displayed following the S-52 Specifications for Chart Content and Display Aspects of ECDIS.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.Layer
member.summary: This is the base class for all geographic data that can be added to the MapView Control.

remarks.para: A Layer is a representation of geographic data portrayed using symbols and text labels. Multiple Layers can be stacked on top of each other to enhance the information displayed for making meaningful decisions. Layers are displayed visually in the Map Control. Layers are drawn bottom to top so the first one in the LayerCollection is drawn first (on the bottom) and each subsequent layer is drawn on top of it, in the order listed.
The first Layer with a valid SpatialReference defines the Map.SpatialReference.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.Layer.MinScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum scale to render this layer at. A large number allows the map to display the layer when zooming further out.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the layer unbounded by any scale.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.Layer.MaxScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum scale to display this layer at. A small number allows the map to display the layer when zooming further in.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the layer unbounded by any scale.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Hydrographic.HydrographicS57Layer.SearchAsync(Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.MapView,Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Geometry.Geometry)
member.summary: Searches the S57 layer asynchronously for features intersecting the provided geometry.
member.param: The MapView to perform the search upon.
member.remarks: The SearchAsync operation takes a spatial geometry object (typically a MapPoint, Polyline, Polygon or Envelope) and returns a collection of S57FeatureObjects which intersect that geometry and/or the provided. Consider alternatively using the overloaded SearchAsync methods which take a buffer distance as a Double, and a S57 object name (acronym) as a String. To perform a search in screen coordinates you should use the or methods.
member.exception: Input geometry must be specified. Use property if necessary.

member.summary: Searches the S57 layer asynchronously for features intersecting the provided geometry buffered by the specified distance.
member.param: The MapView to perform the search upon.
A double representing the buffer distance in meters.
member.exception: Input geometry must be specified. Use property if necessary.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Hydrographic.HydrographicS57Layer.ReferenceScale
member.summary: Gets or sets a layer-wide reference scale for this HydrographicS57Layer.
member.value: A double representing the reference scale. If a double.NaN value is set, the reference scale will be automatically calculated.
member.remarks: By default the reference scale is automatically calculated based on the Cell's compilation scale. However, in some situations it may be necessary to override the default scale and set an alternative scale value. This value will be applied to the layer. To clear a previously defined reference scale, set the property to double.NaN.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Internal.SimpleCache`2
member.summary: Thread safe cache for a small numbers of items.
member.remarks: This holds items by weak reference and attempts to reuse empty slots as objects are released It's using a linear scans to find items, so this is fast for small numbers of items but not so good for large numbers. To prevent constantly growing table it reuses empty weak references in Find and Add calls.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer
member.summary: Dynamic ArcGIS REST map service layer.

remarks.para: An ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer is a dynamic map service published by ArcGIS Server (version 9.3 and higher) using REST. An ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer has the following characteristics:

list.item: It is composed of one or more sub-layers that display some geographic phenomena in a map image.
Map images are generated on-the-fly from ArcGIS Server when requested by the client application.
The background color for the map image will always be transparent when the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ImageFormat is set to use a lossless data compression such as PNG.

The drawing performance is not as fast as cached map images using the ArcGISTiledMapServiceLayer but may be more appropriate for highly focused intra-net applications and applications that are based on real-time or frequently updated data.

Client applications can restrict what sub-layer geographic information is returned in the map image that is generated on-the-fly by setting the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDefinitions, ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerTimeOptions, and ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.VisibleLayers Properties.

example.para: Shows creating an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer in XAML and via code-behind. The ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.InitializeAsync Method is used to obtain metadata about the layer (i.e. ID and Copyright) using the Async/Task framework.

img.alt: Code example using the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer Class.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.DynamicLayer
member.summary: Abstract dynamic layer class

remarks.para: Implement this class if you want to create a custom dynamic layer and want to manage the creation, manipulation or download of the source bitmap data yourself. Note that if you only need to generate a URL to an image you should instead implement . That layer type automatically takes care of downloading the image based on a URL string.

member.name: M:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos
member.summary: Builds a set of DynamicLayerInfo instances based on the current set of LayerInfo instances.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers allow the execution of various ArcGIS Server requests from a client application. An in-depth discussion about Dynamic Layers is in the Fundamentals document: Dynamic Layers. The client side requests that can be issued to ArcGIS Server include the ability to:

list.item: Change the rendering of an existing ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.
Create a layer on-the-fly for the Workspace Types of: Database, Shapefile, FileGDB, and Raster.
Perform table joins.
Query for specific records.
Identify features.
Return raster images.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers are new in ArcGIS Server v10.1.

The key to creating a Dynamic Layer is to set the DynamicLayerInfo.Source Property to the appropriate LayerSource object. The LayerSource is an Abstract Class and has two inherited Classes that should be used in setting the DynamicLayerInfo.Source, they are: LayerDataSource and LayerMapSource. One DynamicLayerInfo object is used per Dynamic Layer and is added to a DynamicLayerInfoCollection which is set to the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.DynamicLayerInfos Property. By default, an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer that was created in ArcMap and served up via ArcGIS Server has its DynamicLayerInfos collection being empty (meaning Nothing/null). Developers can use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method to populate the DynamicLayerInfoCollection to serve as a starting point for creating a Dynamic Layer or they can create individual DynamicLayerInfo objects from scratch and add them to the DynamicLayerInfoCollection.

NOTE: Because creating and using Dynamic Layers requires ArcGIS Server v10.1 and higher, use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ServiceInfo Property to obtain a MapServiceInfo object. Then check that the MapServiceInfo.SupportsDynamicLayers Property = True to ensure that these conditions have been met.

example.para: Demonstrates applying a custom rendering via XAML using the Dynamic Layer option of an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer. Also, shows how to use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method to obtain the original rendering of the layer that was defined in the map service. The CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos is then used to reset the layer back to original rendering.

img.alt: Code example using the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ImageFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the image format.

remarks.para: The default image format is defined by service. There are seven ImageFormat Enumeration values that can be used for the ImageFormat Property, they are:

list.item: Default
JPGPNG
JPG
PNG
PNG8
PNG24
PNG32

remarks.para: The background color for an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer will always be transparent when the ImageFormat is set to use a lossless data compression such as PNG. JPG is considered a lossy data compression and as such will not show the background of the layer to be transparent, meaning it will not drape well over other background layers. Theoretical information related to these compression types can be found for the following topics:

example.para: Shows changing the return ImageFormat for ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer and how that appears visually in the Map.

img.alt: Code example using the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ImageFormat Property.

member.summary: Gets or sets the layer definitions.

remarks.para: Definition expressions for a particular sub-layer LayerID in the LayerDefinition Class that is currently not visible will be ignored by the server.
When the LayerDefinitions Property is not set, all features are returned.
A LayerDefinition of 1=1 returns all features.
For a LayerDefinition that contains an apostrophe embedded within an esriFieldTypeString, escape the apostrophe with a second apostrophe. Example: Name = 'Billy ''O Donald'.

For a LayerDefinition that is based upon a numeric value (i.e. esriFieldTypeDouble, esriFieldTypeInt, etc.) when performing a 'less than' (i.e. the < character) operation in XAML, make sure and escape the syntax with the characters <. Example: Cost < 100.

For ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayers that are served up by ArcGIS Server 10 and above, it is possible to use Time as part of a DATE LayerDefintion. Example: Birthday > DATE '1/15/2008 18:30:00' or Observation1 = DATE '12/27/2008 03:15:00'. For ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayers that are served up by ArcGIS 9.31 and earlier, Time portions of DATE LayerDefinitions are not supported. Use the following syntax instead: Birthday > DATE '1/15/2008' or Observation1 = DATE '12/27/2008'.

TIP: One way to speed up development time in determining the correct LayerDefinition syntax for the ObservableCollection(Of LayerDefinition) is to use Query functionality for the web service in a web browser. The way you do this is via the following steps:

1. Copy the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.URL property into the address bar of the web browser and then click on the hyperlink for the specific sub-layer LayerID you want to perform a Query on. See the following screen shot:

img.alt: Use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.URL property in the address bar of the web browser.

remarks.para: 2. For the specific ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer, scroll to the bottom of the web page and click on the Query hyperlink. See the following screen shot:

img.alt: Click on the Query hyperlink in the web browser.

remarks.para: 3. Specify the LayerDefinition.Definition syntax you want to test in the Where textbox and click either of the Query buttons. Look at the bottom of the page to see if any records have been returned (# results) to know if your LayerDefintion.Definition syntax is correct. See the following screen shot:

img.alt: Use the Where textbox to specify various syntaxes to see how many records are returned.

Also, shows how to use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method to obtain the original rendering of the layer that was defined in the map service. The CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos is then used to reset the layer back to original rendering.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerTimeOptions
member.summary: Gets or sets the layer time options.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions
member.summary: Gets or sets the layer drawing options.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers allow the execution of various ArcGIS Server requests from a client application. An in-depth discussion about Dynamic Layers is in the Fundamentals document: Dynamic Layers. The client side requests that can be issued to ArcGIS Server include the ability to:

list.item: Change the rendering of an existing ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.
Create a layer on-the-fly for the Workspace Types of: Database, Shapefile, FileGDB, and Raster.
Perform table joins.
Query for specific records.
Identify features.
Return raster images.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers are new in ArcGIS Server v10.1.

It is necessary for a Dynamic Layer that will be displayed in a Map Control to have the appropriate Rendering applied. The ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions Property (which is a LayerDrawingOptionCollection Class) is used to set the Rendering of each Dynamic Layer. Like the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.DynamicLayerInfos Property, the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions Property is also empty (meaning Nothing/null) when an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer is created in ArcMap and served up via ArcGIS Server.

There is not a specific Method to generate a LayerDrawingOptionsCollection that is pre-populated with existing Rendering options of the sub-layers in an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer similar to the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method. In order create a new Dynamic Layer using the Rendering of a sub-layer that already exists in an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer, one only needs to specify the DynamicLayerInfo.Source to that of an existing LayerMapSource object.
When creating a new Dynamic Layer and specifying a custom Rendering make sure that the LayerDrawingOptions.LayerID and DynamicLayerInfo.ID match in order for the Dynamic Layer to draw in the Map.

NOTE: Because creating and using Dynamic Layers requires ArcGIS Server v10.1 and higher, use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ServiceInfo Property to obtain a MapServiceInfo object. Then check that the MapServiceInfo.SupportsDynamicLayers Property = True to ensure that these conditions have been met.

example.para: Demonstrates changing the rendering of the first sub-layer of an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer using the Dynamic Layer capabilities of ArcGIS Server 10.1 and higher.

img.alt: Code example using the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions Property.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.DynamicLayerInfos
member.summary: Gets or sets the dynamic layer infos.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers allow the execution of various ArcGIS Server requests from a client application. An in-depth discussion about Dynamic Layers is in the Fundamentals document: Dynamic Layers. The client side requests that can be issued to ArcGIS Server include the ability to:

list.item: Change the rendering of an existing ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.
Create a layer on-the-fly for the Workspace Types of: Database, Shapefile, FileGDB, and Raster.
Perform table joins.
Query for specific records.
Identify features.
Return raster images.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers are new in ArcGIS Server v10.1.

The key to creating a Dynamic Layer is to set the DynamicLayerInfo.Source Property to the appropriate LayerSource object. The LayerSource is an Abstract Class and has two inherited Classes that should be used in setting the DynamicLayerInfo.Source, they are: LayerDataSource and LayerMapSource. One DynamicLayerInfo object is used per Dynamic Layer and is added to a DynamicLayerInfoCollection which is set to the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.DynamicLayerInfos Property. By default, an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer that was created in ArcMap and served up via ArcGIS Server has its DynamicLayerInfos collection being empty (meaning Nothing/null). Developers can use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method to populate the DynamicLayerInfoCollection to serve as a starting point for creating a Dynamic Layer or they can create individual DynamicLayerInfo objects from scratch and add them to the DynamicLayerInfoCollection.

The collection of DynamicLayerInfo objects is used to change the Layer ordering or to redefine the Dynamic Layers drawn in the Map. The order of the objects in the DynamicLayerInfoCollection defines the Layer drawing order; specifically the first element of the collection draws on top of all other Layers.

NOTE: Because creating and using Dynamic Layers requires ArcGIS Server v10.1 and higher, use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ServiceInfo Property to obtain a MapServiceInfo object. Then check that the MapServiceInfo.SupportsDynamicLayers Property = True to ensure that these conditions have been met.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISImageServiceLayer
member.summary: Dynamic ArcGIS REST image service layer.

remarks.para: Allows developers to work with an Image Service resource exposed by the ArcGIS Server REST API (available in ArcGIS Server 9.3 and above). Image Service web services are optimized for delivering raw or finished imagery that can be RGB, panchromatic, multispectral, or elevation data stored in a geodatabase or file system. Data sources for Image Services can be raster datasets, in formats such as TIFF, MrSID, IMAGINE (IMG), or JPEG2000, as well as raster mosaics.

example.para: Shows adding an ArcGISImageServiceLayer via XAML and code-behind. The ArcGISImageServiceLayer.InitializeAsync Method is used to obtain metadata about the layer (i.e. ID and Description) using the Async/Task framework.

img.alt: Example of adding an ArcGISImageServiceLayer to a map via XAML and code-behind.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISImageServiceLayer.Interpolation
member.summary: The resampling process of extrapolating the pixel values while transforming the raster dataset when it undergoes warping or when it changes coordinate space.

remarks.para: The default interpolation method is the NearestNeighbor Enumeration.
There are four ArcGISImageServiceLayer.ImageServiceInterpolation Enumeration values that can be used in the Interpolation Property, they are:

list.item: NearestNeighbor
BilinearInterpolation
CubitConvolution
Majority

remarks.para: Theoretical information related to interpolation can be found for the following topics:

item.a: What is the difference between Nearest Neighbor, Bilinear Interpolation and Cubic Convolution?
Fundamentals for georeferencing a raster dataset
The types of operations in Spatial Analyst

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISImageServiceLayer.CompressionQuality
member.summary: Controls how much data loss the image will be subjected to by the compression algorithm. Valid value ranges of compression quality are from 0 to 100.

remarks.para: The default compression quality is 75. Compression only applies to lossy image types such as JPEG (JPG). PNG is considered a lossless data compression and the CompressionQuality has no effect. If the CompressionQuality property is not set in the code-behind or XAML the getter (Read) will show the CompressionQuality property coming back as Nothing/null.
Support for the JPGPNG format was added at ArcGIS Server 10.0. This format returns a JPG if there are no transparent pixels in the requested extent, otherwise it returns a PNG.
Theoretical information related to compression types can be found for the following topics:

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISImageServiceLayer.BandIds
member.summary: Gets or sets which bands will be displayed (or visible) by the ArcGISImageServiceLayer.

remarks.para: If there are multiple bands, you can either specify a single band to export, or you can change the band combination (red, green, blue) by specifying the band number, for example, [2, 1, 3].
Images are made up of one or more bands. Each band has a single measurable characteristic (such as temperature, elevation, electromagnetic spectrum value, etc.) per pixel.

Typically all of the bands are visible (turned on) by default in the ArcGIS Server service. If the BandIds property is not set in the code-behind the getter (Read) will show the BandIds coming back as Nothing/null.
Theoretical information related to imagery can be found for the following topics:

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.ArcGISImageServiceLayer.NoDataInterpretation
member.summary: Gets or sets the no data interpretation. This property defines how transparency should be evaluated for each pixel and each color band based on the value.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.LayerDrawingOptionCollection
member.summary: A collection of used with the .

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers allow the execution of various ArcGIS Server requests from a client application. An in-depth discussion about Dynamic Layers is in the Fundamentals document: Dynamic Layers. The client side requests that can be issued to ArcGIS Server include the ability to:

list.item: Change the rendering of an existing ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.
Create a layer on-the-fly for the Workspace Types of: Database, Shapefile, FileGDB, and Raster.
Perform table joins.
Query for specific records.
Identify features.
Return raster images.

remarks.para: Dynamic Layers are new in ArcGIS Server v10.1.

It is necessary for a Dynamic Layer that will be displayed in a Map Control to have the appropriate Rendering applied. The ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions Property (which is a LayerDrawingOptionCollection Class) is used to set the Rendering of each Dynamic Layer. Like the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.DynamicLayerInfos Property, the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.LayerDrawingOptions Property is also empty (meaning Nothing/null) when an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer is created in ArcMap and served up via ArcGIS Server.

There is not a specific Method to generate a LayerDrawingOptionsCollection that is pre-populated with existing Rendering options of the sub-layers in an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer similar to the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.CreateDynamicLayerInfosFromLayerInfos Method. In order create a new Dynamic Layer using the Rendering of a sub-layer that already exists in an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer, one only needs to specify the DynamicLayerInfo.Source to that of an existing LayerMapSource object.
When creating a new Dynamic Layer and specifying a custom Rendering make sure that the LayerDrawingOptions.LayerID and DynamicLayerInfo.ID match in order for the Dynamic Layer to draw in the Map.

NOTE: Because creating and using Dynamic Layers requires ArcGIS Server v10.1 and higher, use the ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer.ServiceInfo Property to obtain a MapServiceInfo object. Then check that the MapServiceInfo.SupportsDynamicLayers Property = True to ensure that these conditions have been met.

example.para: Demonstrates using the existing rendering of a Dynamic Layer sub-layer of an ArcGISDynamicMapServiceLayer and switching to a custom rendering defined in code-behind for the Dynamic Layer.

img.alt: Code example using the LayerDrawingOptionCollection Class.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.FeatureLayer
member.summary: ArcGIS Feature Layer display data from either the (1) offline data sources of: or or (2) the online data source of .

remarks.para: Local disk based FeatureLayers DO NOT re-project to match the Map's SpatialReference!

It is recommended to always set the SpatialReference for the Map when using a FeatureLayer based on a local disk based FeatureTable such as a or a . The reason is that the visual elements of the FeatureLayer may not display if the Shapefile or ArcGISFeatureTable are not based on the SpatialReference WKID of 3787 (aka. Web Mercator). By specifying the Map's SpatialReference to be exactly the same at the ShapefileTable or ArcGISFeatureTable, you will be assured that it displays visually in the Map.
If the FeatureLayer is based on an ArcGIS Server web , then re-projection of the data automatically occurs to match the SpatialReference of the Map.

example.para: Shows creating a FeatureLayer in XAML and via code-behind. The FeatureLayer.InitializeAsync Method is used to obtain metadata about the layer (i.e. ID and Copyright) using the Async/Task framework.

img.alt: Adding a FeatureLayer to a map via XAML and code-behind.

member.summary: Performs a hittest against the layer using a System.Windows.Point.
member.param: The MapView to perform the hit test on. The layer must be a member of the map.
Screen coordinate relative to the upper left of the map.
The maximum number of hits. Specify '1' for topmost and fast hittest.
member.returns: The row ids hit if any

remarks.para: When performing a hittest on a FeatureLayer with polygon based features, make sure that a non-transparent FillSymbol style is applied to the Renderer of the FeatureLayer. If no FillSymbol is applied, meaning the polygon fill is considered transparent (even though there may me a polygon outline symbol applied), the hittest will not return an RowID values.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.SourceFields
member.summary: The fields that will be added as attribute of the graphic. The FieldName should match the header name contained inside the CSV file. The FieldType will be used to convert column into that specific data type. If FieldSource is empty or null then all fields will be returned as attributes. If FieldType is not provided field type will default to string.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.XFieldName
member.summary: The name of the column header in the CSV file that contains the data used for the X coordinate.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.YFieldName
member.summary: The name of the column header in the CSV file that contains the data used for the Y coordinate.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.ColumnDelimiter
member.summary: The column delimiter used to split the columns of the CSV file. The default value is comma.

remarks.para: By default it is assumed that the delimiter for the CSV file in parsing data values for between fields is the comma (,). If another delimiter is used (for example a tab or dash) it is required to specify the ColumnDelimiter Property. If the comma is used as the delimiter in the CSV file the ColumnDelimiter Property does not need to be set.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.ServiceUri
member.summary: ServiceUri is the location to the CSV file.

remarks.para: The source of a .csv file can be served up on a web server as a service or locally on disk. If the .csv file is on a web server, the typical format for the string of the ServiceUri Property would be the http:// format (ex: "http://www.mywebserver.com/Cities.csv"). Another alternative for accessing a .csv file can be done via a System.IO.Stream that is set via the CsvLayer.SetSourceAsync Method.

NOTE: Assuming that a .csv file follows the normal conventions of using a comma for the column separator and uses X and Y field names like: X/Y, lat/long, latitude/longitude, etc. it is insufficient for a CsvLayer to display in the map by just setting either the .ServiceUri Property or .SetSourceAsync Method. It is mandatory to create symbology and add it to a Renderer and then set that to the CsvLayer.Renderer Property in order for the CsvLayer to display in the map.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.CsvLayer.SourceSpatialReference
member.summary: The spatial reference of the CSV data.

remarks.para: Unless specified otherwise in the SouceSpatialReference Property, it is assumed that the SpatialReference of the CsvLayer has a WKID value of 4326.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Layers.Graphic
member.summary: Instances of this class represent graphics. Graphics can be displayed on the map through a GraphicsLayer. Graphics can be used as input to a task, or they can be used to display output from a task, or in response to user interaction.

remarks.para: Each graphic must contain an describing the location and the shape of the graphic.

A graphic can be associated with an which determines how the graphic looks. Alternatively, the graphics layer can be assigned an which determines the appearance of all graphics in the layer. Note, symbols associated with individual graphics take precedence over the symbols chosen by the renderer. The symbol used depends upon the geometry type associated with the graphic. A is used for and geometries, for geometries, and for geometries.
A graphic can contain a set of attributes (key-value pairs) providing more information about the graphic.

member.name: T:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.GraphicsOverlay
member.summary: A collection of vector graphics for overlaying on the map

remarks.para: GraphicsOverlays allow you to associate a collection of Graphic elements with the MapView. Graphics have geometry and attributes that are stored in memory, and therefore must be built programmatically and are not persisted. A GraphicsOverlay always displays on top of all layers in the map, but below any map overlay elements. It displays over any Map you put in the map view and will automatically adjust if the spatial reference changes. While able to display more elements than a map overlay, because they are stored in memory graphics overlays are designed to display a moderate number of features that belong more with your application rather than with a particular map. Graphics are best suited for displaying map information that is specific to the current user session or things that need to be displayed temporarily. Showing query results or buffer polygons on the map are examples suited to using a GraphicsOverlay.
NOTE: Because they are not in the map, graphics in overlays will not appear in a map's legend or be displayed when the map is printed.

example.para: Demonstrates using the Query.FindTask operation to return county features in an ArcGIS Server map service and display the features found as Graphics in a GraphicsOverlay. The user can perform a MapViewTapped on the Graphics to perform a GraphicsOverlay.HitTestAsync to select features and display attribute information.

img.alt: Performing a GraphicsOverlay.HitTestAsync on Graphic in a GraphicsOverlay.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.GraphicsOverlay.MinScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum scale to render this layer at. A large number allows the map to display the layer when zooming further out.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the layer unbounded by any scale.

member.name: P:Esri.ArcGISRuntime.Controls.GraphicsOverlay.MaxScale
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum scale to display this layer at. A small number allows the map to display the layer when zooming further in.

remarks.para: A scale is usually referred to as 1:X, where X is the scale specified here. This value is the relative scale to the real world, where on inch on the screen is X inches in the real world. Note that this is only an approximation and is dependent on the map's projection that can add some distortion, as well as the system's reported DPI setting which doesn't necessarily match the actual DPI of the screen.
The default value of this property is which makes the layer unbounded by any scale.
